content.question: Three identical blocks, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, hang from identical strings, as shown in the figure. Which of the following free-body diagrams could represent the forces exerted on block <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The figure presents a free body diagram on a grid. The diagram consists of two labeled arrows extending from a point. An arrow labeled F sub Tension Up, end sub, extends vertically upward, and is 2 units in length. An arrow labeled F sub Gravity extends vertically downward, and is 2 units in length.

The figure presents a free body diagram on a grid. The diagram consists of three labeled arrows extending from a point. An arrow labeled F sub Tension Up, end sub, extends vertically upward, and is 4 units in length. An arrow labeled F sub Tension Down, end sub, extends vertically downward, and is 2 units in length. An arrow labeled F sub Gravity also extends vertically downward, and is 2 units in length.

content.answer: The figure presents a free body diagram on a grid. The diagram consists of three labeled arrows extending from a point. An arrow labeled F sub Tension Up, end sub, extends vertically upward, and is 4 units in length. An arrow labeled F sub Tension Down, end sub, extends vertically downward, and is 2 units in length. An arrow labeled F sub Gravity also extends vertically downward, and is 2 units in length.
